job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: - Respected - Good employees and people to work with
cons: - Shifts could be on any day

job_title: Gardener in Torpoint, England
pros: Beautiful Garden Great variety of work Excellent volunteers
cons: Not enough staff to raise the profile of the garden.

job_title: Contractor in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: great team good training great building to work in good benefits
cons: sometimes slow in proceeding with initiatives

job_title: Food and Beverage in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Friendly property team, supportive and hard working.
cons: Toxic management. You are not valued, you only get on if you have something that gains them and as soon as you are of no value, you are cast aside and treat like your not even there

job_title: N A in Orford, England
pros: There are no pros for working at the NT. They take advantage of free labour and toss you to the wind.
cons: Labour is replaceable, even low level management is in the firing line for whatever new project they may have on the cards. Charity funds are poured into the wind as they just expect more funding year on year, I am currently in contact with the whistleblower chat line due to their massive mismanagement.

review_title: Good starting job, with good salary but boring
job_title: Catering Assistant in Bookham, England
pros: Good pay, nice people, flexible hours, variety of jobs.
cons: can be very boring at times and hard work when busy.

job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Skegness, England
pros: Flexible hours Beautiful workplace Good holiday allowanxe
cons: Disorganised High employee turnover Terrible staff culture Dissatisfied customers Disconnect from managers

job_title: Visitor Experience Assistant in Sudbury, East Midlands, England
pros: Nice place to work but average pay
cons: Long days standing up in all weathers

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Beautiful places to work Worked alongside some lovely and passionate staff & volunteers
cons: Incredibly toxic and cliquey working environment, if your face didn’t fit then you were actively ‘bullied’ by the ones who were ‘in’. Thousands of pounds wasted on frivolous things or unfinished projects, not to mention the fact that ‘mates’ within the building trade, were given lucrative contracts to undertake projects. Management weren’t interested in hearing any other story, other than the one that they had chosen to believe. This wasn’t just at a property level, it went all the way up to regional. Under qualified people were given promotions, based on their ability to talk a good job. Sadly they were often unable to actually do the said job! Front line staff were expected to bring in the money for the property, yet they were often on the basic level pay and zero hour/short term contracts, offering them no reliability, leading to high staff turn over. These are just the headlines….

job_title: Assistant Gardener in Salisbury, England
pros: nice surroundings to work in
cons: more about working around increasingly kitchy events than tending to the historical garden

job_title: Retail Manager in Grasmere, England
pros: They mean we'll, yhe hours and benefits are good, the pay is fair and the fact you are helping to support the vital work of the Trust is awesome.
cons: They are not mentally equipped to think about profitability which represents itself is numerous ways. Shops are either woefully under or over stocked, with such a variety of locations, the ability of shop managers to tailor what they stock to their property is woeful and in general the beurocracy is worse than any company I have ever ever worked for. Both in volume and in unnecessary complexity. Like I said. They mean we'll but are mostly useless.

job_title: Chef in Brighton, England
pros: Great pension scheme. Daytime shifts
cons: Restrictive cookbook. Poor management structure

job_title: Assistant Director in Bristol, England
pros: Amazing people and a terrific job
cons: Pay is not as compatible as equivalent in private sector but if you are after purpose - that will not be top of your list of priorities.

review_title: Better than most entry level jobs, but you don't work for a charity.
job_title: Team Member in Ilam, England
pros:
Wonderful job setting, especially in properties listed in national parks.

Without a doubt you will have kinder work colleagues, one of the best large companies when it comes to this.

Zero hours contract means flexibility regarding hours.
cons:
Zero hours contract means that you don't get a great deal of notice if they need you in earlier or don't need you at all that day (within a matter of hours and on the same day).

Like all jobs it depends on management, if your line manager likes an incompetant employee, they aren't going anywhere.

My main issues are as follows:
In my case most supervisors have had little confidence in their opinions and follow the line manager in all things, regardless of issues raised by team members like myself.

Like all companies the culture and values are treated like a great many things in this world, they are carried out with the attitude of 'if we have time' rather than 'we will make the time' meaning that they are carried out at a managers discretion. 

Worst of all more in depth training from managers and supervisors on something as simple as a coffee machine, an essential for my job role, is not guaranteed; if you don't ask you don't get.

job_title: Food and Beverage Supervisor in Leominster, England
pros: Lovely colleagues, good training and good support available
cons: Long hours, hard work and very low pay with little pay review

job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in London, England
pros: Good pay I guess lol
cons: very stressful if u r in popular sites

review_title: Life enhancing, apart from the pay
job_title: Visitors Experience in Sheffield, England
pros: Great ethos within my department, the work seems to attract good people, widely referred to as second family. Worthy cause, there's a point to what you do, and in a beautiful place as well. Finally seems like the NT is ready to begin putting its inclusive principles into action rather than just talking the talk and thinking that's enough.
cons: Low pay for the work, especially for starters. Face fits culture becoming less of an issue, but still a thing.

review_title: Good work if you can get it
job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Manchester, England
pros: Good colleagues and great work environment
cons: locations can be a bit out of the way and pay could be better

job_title: Visitor Experience Volunteer in London, England
pros: Friendly team, nice environment and a beautiful place to work in.
cons: Not many downsides- a need to work on weekends and being outside in all weather's.

review_title: Culture and community gone since pandemic
job_title: Administration in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Salary Work tasks Remote /hybrid
cons: Not enough diversity No community and lack of culture Progression only happens for the loud and seen Roles can feel isolating if you're not part of a team Middle management lack inclusive and empathetic leadership

job_title: Membership & Visitor Welcome Manager in Moy, Northern Ireland
pros: The National Trust is a tremendous organisation, which I was proud to work for. The property is beautiful, the estate is a little bit of heaven!
cons: At the time newly promoted management were on a power trip. I was purposely over worked in order to fail. They didn't support my mental health disability and the area director believed that the senior management staff required no further training on working with staff with disabilities.

review_title: Great benefits but lots of red tape
job_title: Gardener in Shrewsbury, England
pros: Good company benefits, pension, sick pay etc.
cons: Lots of red tape and procedures to follow, too many meetings and not enough getting done!

job_title: Assistant Gardener in Henley on Thames, England
pros: The other gardeners and the garden itself. Also able to work flexibly.
cons: Poor management. Lost over 10 members of staff in the 9 months I was there. Would not recommend accepting a job there.

job_title: Head Office Employee in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Friendly people, everyone believes in the values and core purpose, flexible working, generally not too much micro-management. The work is interesting. Free entry to properties for you plus one and 20% off in shop and cafe.
cons: Lack of options for progression which means talented people often leave. PDR process isn't transparent. Lots of travel but no time off in lieu. Have to use annual leave to book Christmas so essentially only 20 days off. Low mood since huge round of redundancies back in 2020 and it still hasn't picked up.

job_title: Retail Team Member in Exeter, England
pros: Good management, understanding of staff's personal situations, work life balance encouraged, relaxing work environment, good cause.
cons: The pay is quite low, there often isn't a chance to work more than part time hours.

job_title: Visitor Experience Officer in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Good team atmosphere, great to work outdoors and meet lots of different people, great experience helping the promotion of history, nature, sustainability and conservation.
cons: Depending on the site - can involve irregular season based hours, some problems with pay and contracts, established and top-heavy middle management can create unproductive culture.

job_title: Assistant Manager in Cardiff, Wales
pros: Job for life with like minded people who believed they were working for a worthwhile charity
cons: No loyalty to long serving staff, very business driven and charity status being lost in drive to make a profit above all else

job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Llanfair, Wales
pros: Consistent shifts Friendly staff members Good pay
cons: Lots of time on your feet Can be very busy Very short breaks

job_title: Collections Specialist in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Friendly, supportive, encouraging, give responsibility, flexible
cons: Long hours, busy, multi tasking, xx, xx

job_title: Gardens in Newtownards, Northern Ireland
pros: Nice surroundings, gardens and buildings
cons: Absentee managers and bullying is rife

job_title: Cafe Assistant in Southampton, England

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England

job_title: Food and Beverage Team Member in Sevenoaks, England

job_title: Catering Assistant in Ripon, England

job_title: Manager in Bridgwater, England
pros:
Give back and conserve for the future generation to
Enjoy

job_title: Coordinator in London, England
pros:
Locations are generally beautiful
I worked with a great on-site team
Free admission to nationwide properties and car parks
cons: The charity doesn't seem to realise it's a charity, so little or no fundraising goes on yet properties are struggling to stay afloat. It's also unsure whether it's there to show and teach people about history and heritage or as a fun family day out, and the two can clash with horrendous consequences. Head office has no idea what's going on at property level and doesn't seem to care whether their 'big picture' strategies are actually going to work on a practical, local level. Properties are losing their individual identities because they're having to follow head office strategies ie. homogeneous shops and cafes and generic events. Properties are generally understaffed, underpaid and stretched but head office just keeps on recruiting more and more high-salaried consultants. You are expected to go way beyond your job description which would be fine if salaries were a little better.

review_title: Mixed Bag - should be great but it isn't

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Newtownards, Northern Ireland

job_title: Catering Assistant in Banchory, Scotland

job_title: Catering Assistant in Reading, England

review_title: Supportive organisation but retail plays a minor role, slow to change

Supportive employer
Great mission

job_title: Occupational Therapy in London, England

job_title: Catering & Retail Assistant in Sevenoaks, England

job_title: Business Support in Kendal, England

quite hierachical

job_title: Consultancy Manager in York, England

job_title: Food &Amp; Beverage Assistant in Worksop, England

job_title: Catering Assistant in Leatherhead, England

job_title: Food & Beverage Manager in Rotherfield Greys, England

job_title: General Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England

review_title: Good place for students and young people
job_title: Catering Assistant in Stowe, England
pros: Fun environment, Flexible hours, Varied work
cons:
Can get very busy 
Management is sometimes a bit all over the shop

job_title: Cafe Assistant in Guildford, England
pros: Friendly staff and lots of workplace flexibility.
cons: High staff turnover due to mismanagement.

job_title: Senior Marketing and Communications Officer in Bristol, England
pros: On site teams are wonderful, beautiful places to work
cons:
Executive team do not engage or ask property staff what they think, despite many decades of experience. 
This results in wasted time, money and low employee morale as higher level staff ignore good advice from teams.

job_title: Food and Bervage Assistant in Nottingham, England
pros: The pay and the company benefits
cons: The long hours of work

job_title: Project Manager in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: Supportive, friendly, great team Environment and lots of development opportunities
cons: Very slow at getting anything done

job_title: Catering Assistant in Wilmslow, England
pros: Such a lovely work environment and great co-workers.
cons: Sometimes miscommunication between kitchen and FOH.

review_title: Great if you work in conservation
job_title: Commercial Manager in Exeter, England
pros: Excellent benefits and conditions - work/life balance
cons: Commercial staff and "second class citizens" there to make money only

job_title: Food and Beverage Team Leader in Uckfield, England
pros:
Great for younger staff to gain confidence in working with the public, in a busy tea room and a wide demographic of staff
Tends to be a super friendly team around you
When changes happen they are often for the best
Working for an organisation that had great intentions
Semi-flexible hours
Perks of getting family in free to NT sites and staff discount
cons:
Way too much is expected from staff, given their job role and pay check
No perks for working overtime or bank holidays -just something that you’re expected to do. 
Behind the times. Catering department seems to be a good 4-5 years behind the rest of the food industry in what they can provide 
Restricted by a ridiculous ‘cookbook’ that’s out dated and has a negative impact on the enjoyment of customers which ultimately effects the work ethic of staff who can only apologise for the type/variety of food presented
Staff moral is often very low 
A large devise between the ‘front of house’ staff and the office staff- creates a conflict between what the pencil pushers want and what the FOH staff are actually able to provide

job_title: IT Project Manager in Didcot, England
pros: Nice staff and head office location.
cons: Poor leadership within IT, it needs a change of direction

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Canterbury, England
pros:
good team to be involved in 
lovely environment
cons: unpredictable hours sometimes due to seasonal contract

review_title: Good people and a worthy organisation
job_title: People Development Advisor in Birmingham, England
pros: good people, lovely places to work.
cons: very hierarchical, bit of a behemoth

job_title: Booking Coordinator in Antrim, Northern Ireland
pros: Discounts at certain retailers, access to NT properties free for you and your partner, good sick pay
cons:
Handled the pandemic shockingly. 
Management structure is top heavy and so the people on the ground are always worst affected.

job_title: Catering Assistant in West Hoathley, England
pros: Lovely people to work with
cons: Sometimes filled over capacity which was stressful

job_title: Marketing Campaign Executive in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: People are great, work life balance is great
cons: Little to no progression with minimal development structures in place

job_title: Product Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Clear HR processes, work hard on staff engagement at strategic level.
cons: Diverse organisation with multiple strategic aims, resulting in lots of politics stakeholder management which is like wading through treacle to get even simple things achieved.

job_title: Catering Assistant in Sheffield, England
pros:
flexible for uni students
overtime in the summer
cons:
long busy days
late notice for rotas

job_title: Project Manager in High Wycombe, England
pros: They care about their workforce
cons: Decision making is slow as they take opinion from a wide range of stakeholders

job_title: Food and Beverages in Hammersmith, England
pros: The people working with you on the front line
cons: Bullying organisation , and managers sit around not doing a lot

review_title: Lovely job for a zero-hour contract
job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Sevenoaks, England
pros: Very good holiday job for when I am not at university.
cons: I do not have anything bad to say

review_title: Overall great organisation to work for
job_title: Visitor Experience Assistant in Ashford, Kent, South East England, England
pros:
Friendly staff
Lovely working environment
Discounts and memberships
Training provided
cons:
Low wages
Occasional weekend and evening work

job_title: Room Guide in Chelsea, England

cons: None, a lovely place to wor

job_title: Tour Guide in Bushmills, Northern Ireland
pros: Fun, busy, pay is very good, meet lots of people
cons: little cold and can be dangerous depending on where you are

job_title: Visitor Experience Officer in Manchester, England
pros: none none none none none
cons: great employer ....joy to work for

job_title: Assistant in Bromley, England
pros: Money is ok from time to time
cons: Money is bad from time to time

job_title: Ops Manager in Bridgwater, England
pros:
good support 
good benefits 
lovely sites
cons:
days of work 
lack of budgets 
too many chefs!

job_title: Senior Project Coordinator in Birmingham, England
pros: Everyone is lovely and caring and the work is doing good in this world
cons: So. Many. People. So very many employees.

job_title: Catering Assistant in Dorking, England
pros: friendly place to work, always willing to give you shifts
cons: Sometimes too busy to have lunch break

review_title: Food and Beverage Team Member - Part time
job_title: Food and Beverage Team Member in Falmouth, England
pros: Lovely people to work with, friendly atmosphere.
cons: Can get very busy at times

job_title: Retail Assistant in York, England
pros:
Great working conditions
Great pay
Good socials
cons: Felt pressured to sell expensive items

job_title: Project Manager in London, England
pros: Really care about their people
cons: Can be less efficient due to people's needs coming first

job_title: Food and Beverage Team Member in Shrewsbury, England
pros: - Fellow staff are lovely and friendly.
cons:
- The National Trust are zero hours employees which ordinarily you can accept however when you get told it's "for the best of the Trust" and "remember we're a charity" over and over again it does begin to grate.

- As it's zero hours management likes to blacklist people they don't like, a colleague called in sick so they didn't give her hours for a month forcing her to quit.

- I was given shifts in the kitchen despite not even having a GCSE in Food tech, and I didn't even have to complete online training.

- When I started working there they promise opportunities for learning and development, however I've never been offered anything and neither have any others colleagues.

- Not given proper chemical training when I started simply told to sign a document saying I had done the training.

- Often given unrealistic expectations in a certain time frame, for example I've been expected to close the 300 seat cafe I work in, in an hour a simply impossible task.

- Because you're zero hours they seem to take that as permission to cut your shift half way through the day.

- They promise you benefits from working there, primarily a national trust membership staff card, I've been there a year and have yet to receive one.

- I have had management secretly listen to my conversations to customers only to then be called up into the office to be told off for "talking badly about management".

job_title: Business Analyst in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Supportive flexible company with a good range of interesting project
cons: Large organisation so the levels of rigor and structure that accompany this

job_title: Assistant Chef in Warwick, North West England, England
pros: Beautiful location, great place to be
cons: Redundant due to Covid sadly

job_title: Marketing Officer in Derby, England
pros: Good people, understanding culture, aspirational values, great benefits
cons: The Interview process might be quite demanding for some

job_title: Marketing Assistant in Stowe, England
pros: Great progression and experience - learnt from the best
cons: Nothing - really loved my time there

job_title: Catering Assistant in Bristol, England
pros:
I've found there to be brilliant leadership within my team at the NT. Each individual team - looking after the different areas of the sites - are friendly, supportive and always work as a team. I feel encouraged and looked after when I am working, as well as challenged. 
The team I work with are target oriented and are always working hard to meet the public's needs. We are a diverse lot and many of us on the team are young, so it's wonderful to see lots of budding individuals taking an interest in such an important charity.
cons: While there is excellent communication within the team, I feel that each team within each NT site (I speak mainly for our site from experience) could do with communicating a little more often with one another to ensure proper smooth running. I also feel that positive ideas should be easier to share within the company as a whole.

review_title: Low pay, but stable employment with good perks
job_title: House Steward in Preston, North West England, England
pros: Staff are generally friendly across sites and the perks are good (more annual leave than average and discounts at gyms/shops). As it is such a big organisation, most roles are fairly stable.
cons:
The pay is low unless you’re in upper management (who seem to outnumber regular employees and are
paid 4x as much) and complaints are rarely dealt with.

review_title: At points one of the best times in my working career....................
job_title: Senior Head of Department in London, England
pros: Great team atmosphere, ethic and spirit. The training and personal development is some of the best I have ever experienced. Commitment to a worthwhile cause, with shared decision makes for a fantastic shared experience. Innovating, inspiring and at times blue sky thinking.
cons: Change can be a positive factor but only if you are made to feel part of the change. If you face does not fit it becomes apparent and you are progressively left outside of the change instead of supporting a colleague.

review_title: Inspiring place with room to grow
job_title: Social Media Executive in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros:
Working for a common cause
Genuinely good people to work with
Plenty of career progression
Ability to use all sorts of skills
cons: Things take AGES to be agreed and do (but it is a large organisation)

review_title: Lovely staff and places, poor pay and opportunities
job_title: Business Support Coordinator in Kendal, England
pros: NT staff are generally really nice, working in beautiful places is a joy and there is a feeling of satisfaction supporting a good organisation.
cons: Pay for most staff is poor, the bureaucracy is frustrating and systems and processes are constantly changing. There is little scope for progression from operations into the better paid roles.

review_title: Feels like a family business but needs to move with the times
job_title: Business Support in London, England
pros:
Opportunities to step up (you just won't be rewarded for it)
Broadly speaking the people are good, but there are bad eggs
The charity and what they do is fabulous
All the money goes where it should - to doing our work. Genuinely feel proud to work for them
cons:
Lots of people have been here forever and are under performing. They halt the progress of others and the progress of the Trust
Long hours - they ask an awful lot of you for pretty terrible pay.
The public can treat you awfully.
Fairly toothless management - no one is prepared to rock the boat so they let bad behaviour by some carry on so as not to have to discipline
Poor benefits and holidays
No career progression in business support at all

review_title: Ranger - Opportunities, meeting people, learning skill, and unique experiences.
job_title: Ranger in Chirk, Wales
pros:
Having lots of volunteers, groups and colleagues is a brilliant way meeting like minded people from lots of different back grounds. 
Being able to implement new and exciting ideas into events with lots of support is amazing!
Going around the country on various meeting, conferences and gathering is another way of meeting great people, and gaining inspiration off others.
Training is always key and no expense is spared.
cons: Last minute difficulties come into play when implementing new ideas or events is stressful, and constant change of trending focus, techniques and campaigns is hard to grasp when previous trends are still in progress.

review_title: Not really  the conservation charity that it purports to be...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bury St Edmunds, England
pros:
Looks good on your CV.
Good holiday entitlement.
Many good colleagues.
Free access to Trust properties.
Allows promotion by moving to other regions and properties.
cons:
Mostly incompetent senior managers, there to build their own careers.
Few Managers are leaders.
HR is concerned only with mitigating risk from employee claims.
Rule-bound and process-driven.
Poor pay unless you reach senior management level.
Accountants have far too much influence leading to cheap, rather than good value, results.
Completely overworks staff and there is no time to take time off in lieu.

review_title: Inspiring mission statement, problematic delivery,  poor management
job_title: IT Consultant in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Some inspiring and very talented people. Interesting & challenging projects to work on. Reasonable pay and pension benefits. Open to flexible working.
cons: Organisational culture is rather  homogeneous - mostly white middle class people at head office. Too much power in the hands of line managers, 'face fits' attitudes to challenging poor management behaviour. Lack of team cohesion, due to old-fashioned hierarchical management structures. Lack of effective project & resource management. Some salary offers below market rates, worth negotiating. Most full-time roles are fixed-term contracts.

review_title: Catering - fun, friendly, a little disorganised
job_title: Cafe Assistant in Exeter, England
pros: Friendly atmosphere, providing a professional service, not often boring because of the daily interaction with customers, ideal if you like small close-knit staff teams
cons: From experience, it can be a little disorganised (management choosing to under rather than over staff on potentially busy days) which can make for a stressful atmosphere. Luckily this sort of occurrence did not often happen.

review_title: Lovely people, lovely places, but beware the committee culture
job_title: Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: I made some great friends here. It's good to be able to work for a cause you believe in and they're doing some pretty cutting edge stuff which most charities aren't able to.
cons: Paralysed by endless committees, risk aversion and a complete inability to take decisions. Insecure fixed term contracts and salaries, although reasonable for the voluntary sector, were 30% below market rates in my field. Hierarchical structure means lots of emphasis on sucking up to the boss while ideas and expertise at a more junior level are wasted.

job_title: Business Support Coordinator in London, England
pros:
The NT really cares about its job in looking after the many places it’s responsible for 
Work life balance is good
Females in leadership positions 
There are many staff members who genuinely care and it is because of these people that so much good is done
cons:
Salary 
Bureaucracy - meetings about meetings, having conferences because we’ve said we’re going to not because there is any real need or major benefit

job_title: Visitor Experience Officer in Royal Tunbridge Wells, England
pros: The people are lovely and everyone works as a team to create the best environment for visitors. It’s great to work for a company with such strong beliefs and appreciation for our places and people. Usually the commute is great, the places are beautiful and the job is pretty chilled with great hours and benefits.
cons: The pay isn’t great, but I guess that’s the decision to work for a charity! Also find that if you’re at the bottom of the pack you don’t often get your views heard.

job_title: Forester in Royston, East of England, England
pros:
As an organisation it’s overall goals are spot on
The work is for a worthy cause and many places do look after heir staff
cons: As usual with almost all big companies and I say company because the NT behaves more like them then a charity, they suffer from some very poor management mostly because of the employees chosen. Not many have worked through the ranks and its startlingly obvious by some of the school boy errors through lack of experience

review_title: Lovely place to work but very busy
job_title: Catering Assistant in Aberystwyth, Wales
pros: Worked with the best team of people, colleagues were all lovely and supportive, always helping each other/working great as a team. Flexible hours meant we had a a lot of say in when we could and couldn't work. Lovely environment and property to work at with benefit of getting free entrance to all National Trust properties!
cons: Sometimes we were very understaffed which made the job incredibly unnecessarily stressful. Layout of tearoom also needs changing and should be self service rather than waitress service. Sometimes not given enough hours if you want a 5 day working week.

job_title: Visitor Experience Assistant in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros: You got to meet lots of new people. It was fun dressing up in costume and performing. The team were very strong. No two days are the same at work.
cons: At times it was cold. Sometimes you would be asked to work longer shifts than expected. It would get quite busy and there wouldn't be enough staff sometimes.

job_title: Business and Finance Administrator in York, England
pros: At a NT Proerty you can will be working at a potentially beautiful location and the job will be different every day so you will never get board.
cons: There is often an expectation that you will go over and above your contracted working hours as and when required as part of your job which doesn't always work for everyone.

review_title: A good stable job which is hard work but also rewarding.
job_title: Catering Assistant in Plymouth, England
pros: I have met a great team working for the trust. its nice to know you are contributing to a charity. personal ability and growth within catering.
cons: minimum wage does not seem worthy of the hard work I put in sometimes. It takes its toll on your body (bad back, aching legs)

review_title: If you like buildings and nature, you’ll love it.  If that’s not your thing, you won’t feel part of the gang
job_title: Director in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros:
interesting work
ok budgets
good sized teams
cons:
doing way too much at any one time
terrible decision making - love to talk, never decide
if you’re in any way diverse - you’ll find it tough

job_title: Conservation Assistant in London, England
pros: Lovely place to work, everyone is very friendly and enthusiastic about the Trust and the work they do.
cons: The pay is very low. For internships, they are 'voluntary' so you will often not get paid at all, but instead given a benefit such as accommodation.

job_title: Volunteer in Newport, Newport, Wales
pros: Great locations to volunteer at, you work with some varied people and no 2 days are ever the same
cons: The NT is a charity and the salaries reflect that (unless it's senior management of course) so the site management tends to be either inexperienced or average in quality.

job_title: Catering Assistant in London, England
pros: Good pay (if you're a student) and friendly working environment. Nice to get free lunch as well and some managers very interested in staff development
cons: Worked in hospitality, often quite stressful and no contingency plans for manager illness. Limited opportunities for promotion. Other than that, pretty good place to work!

job_title: Visitor Services Manager in Dorchester, South West England, England
pros: Great team and work setting. Lovely volunteers. Staff perks are ok.
cons: Budget targets set too high, extremely difficult to get things done or repaired. Money wasted on big corporate days when it could be used to get rid of repairs back log.  Low pay for expectations.

job_title: Sales Assistant in Bodiam, South East England, England
pros:
Free entry to national trust properties 20per cent off purchases in cafe and shop .Lovely settings to work around.
Holiday and sick pay
cons: .Some heavy lifting required during delivery times .Can be extremely busy .Staff room facilities and working conditions not great

job_title: Holidays Operative in Callington, England
pros: I think the 20% off in the shop and holiday cottage bookings is an incentive for employees.  However, the cottage prices are extortionate so employees can get something similar for less money anyway.
cons: They expect to underpin their charity status by employing people on a low wage and have hidden expectations of employees for which they do not offer remuneration.  They see this as having a "can do" attitude, ie. you must give up your own time and efforts for free to get on.  You also have to be at their beck and call every day as all the cottages can be let on imminent short lets basis.

job_title: Holiday Home Caretaker in Brixham, England
pros: Friendly atmosphere, good pay, easy job and nice friendly customers to interact with. In addition, pay was always on time and with pay slips (which increasingly seems to be a problem to get hold of)
cons: It was long hours,there were no real perks to working for the national trust, and I felt a bit undervalued; as in noone cared about the quality of my work, only that it was done!

job_title: Programmer Lead in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Great cause to work for.  Dedicated and diverse workforce.  Flexible working arrangements.  Interesting work and great people to work with.
cons: It can be challenging and slow moving to push through change.  At times direction from different areas of the organisation felt unaligned.

review_title: Bad management in catering and bullying culture
job_title: Catering Assistant in Stowe, England
pros: Some nice co workers to work with
cons: Terrible Managers in catering , the managers get away with doing what they want and treating staff however they want , it is a really bad environment

review_title: Everything you would expect from the NT
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: The National Trust is a brilliant organisation to work for, it is filled with passionate and dedicated people who worked hard to support the strategy. I work centrally at Heelis and find the working environment relaxed and inclusive.  There is plenty of opportunity to progress and develop.
cons: The IT systems need to be improved to allow for agile working.

job_title: Catering Assistant in Uckfield, England
pros: It is a stunning place to work. Worked with a great team. Pays a minimum of living wage for all employees.
cons:
Constantly under staffed, especially during peak busy period.
Badly organised, e.g: rota's changed without staff informed, order's not processed in time so delivery doesn't turn up.
Zero hour contracts (but you get holiday and sick pay).

review_title: Fun Mostly. Disconnected because of size
job_title: Membership and Welcome Assistant in London, England
pros:
People that you work with are usually friendly and close knit.
Visitors are more than likely friendly and interested in what they are looking at.
Surroundings are always beautiful
cons:
Expenses claims are slow
Opinions of lower level staff usually not listened to.
Tight targets

review_title: Nice people. Date systems and processes
job_title: Catering Assistant in Stowe, England
pros: The people make the workplace and the work itself can be fun and sometimes rewarding. Once you learn the ropes the job becomes actually enjoyable
cons: National trust has several archaic, boring processes that need following eg the cookbook that needs following. Moreover at some locations politics can arise

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
- Beautiful places, both indoors and out 
- Friendly people
- Good aims
cons:
Bureaucratic 
Beholden to identity politics 
If your face doesn’t fit you won’t progress
Poor pay

review_title: Great cause with some great people
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros:
A sense of doing something positive for the future
Ideas are listened to
internal moves are encouraged
cons: As a charity salaries don’t always compete with bigger corporate firms

job_title: Operations Manager in Salisbury, England
pros: Reliable and great career progression
cons: Lower salary than comparative roles outside of the charity sector.

job_title: Visitor Operations Manager in High Wycombe, England
pros: The people are fantastic here. It’s like a big family and the passion they bring to their work is admirable.
cons: The workload is massive. Teams at property level are kept small and the pay is poor,

job_title: Catering Assistant in Worcester, England
pros: Great working environment, nice co-workers, interaction with the public, trained professionally in health and safety, chance to develop communication and interpersonal skills. Good cultural values
cons: You only know when you will be working within <7 days notice which can make it difficult to plan other commitments

review_title: Great team, great place, good work.
job_title: Marketing and Communications Assistant in Cardiff, Wales
pros:
Get to work and visit some of the UK's best places.

Work as part of great teams that genuinely enjoy what they do.

Get to play a role in a genuinely good cause.

Great job perks.
cons: Tough to climb the job ladder at property level.

job_title: Weekend Supervisor Retail in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Great shop, wonderful colleagues, good team who have pulled together after a bad experience.
cons: Management not taking our concerns seriously.

job_title: Visitor Operations Team Member in Bath, England
pros:
amazing support from site managers and wider national trust
NT card for you and a guest
great working environments
get to contribute to a worth cause
work feels worthwhile
cons:
average wage
something locations are difficult to get to

job_title: Gardener in London, England
pros: Still great to interact with Visitors, most staff are still brilliant. As a whole they care for their staff and their well being
cons: Some Managers are struggling to cope with the pressures

job_title: Catering Assistant in Charlecote, England
pros: Friendly colleagues. Beautiful location. Opportunity to engage in a variety of catering tasks. Management respected you and valued your opinion and progression.
cons: Catering was let down by the lack of restaurant facilities which led to complaints on behalf of the customers.

job_title: Food and Beverage Team Member in Mottisfont, England
pros:
Great hours
Great team 
Good Ethos behind the company 
Good training 
Profit goes to their charity and to help the other properties and land
cons: Need a car to get there ideally as train station is a walk away across fields

review_title: Good leadership, innovative business, customer focussed
job_title: Catering Assistant in Leatherhead, England
pros: Career development and opportunities, fair employee treatment, opportunity for promotion, fair pay.
cons: High customer turnover - very busy days during high season. No time and a half on Sundays or Bank Holidays.

job_title: Head of Digital in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Great cause and free family membership
cons: Limited opportunities to progress - once you’re in the door you’ll often leave in the same position.

job_title: Catering Assistant in Reading, England
pros:
Nice people to work with
Can be fun to work sometimes
cons:
As soon as you have experience you're relied on too heavy for how busy it gets.
Tea-room manager is only around when not busy

job_title: Food and Beverage Assistant in Dunstable, England
pros: Flexible hours, rewarding job and good pay
cons: There is sometimes a lack in communication between departments and from mangers, but on the whole not too bad

job_title: Catering Assistant in Brownsea Island, England
pros:
Everyone is very friendly
The scenery at the property that I work at is beautiful
Good pay
Staff Discount at other National Trust properties
cons: In some properties, the equipments are a bit old and need to be replaced

job_title: Marketing Campaign Executive in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Flexible working, friendly team, lots of training available
cons: Slow progression, lots of sign off involved by lots of different people can be tedious and slow projects down.
